author: ghost
body:
tldr; change default pwsh prompt to use OSC 9;9, so that people can create a new tab in Windows Terminal with same working directory as current tab.

## Summary of the new feature/enhancement

wrt https://github.com/microsoft/terminal/issues/8166 

Windows Terminal recently added support for OSC 9;9 which is required for creating a new tab with the same working directory. How this works is that the prompt contains the path to the working directory wrapped in osc 9;9 which is used by the Windows Terminal to read the path and create new tab in same path.

Currently, people have to manually modify the powershell prompt to include OSC 9;9 like this https://gist.github.com/skyline75489/480d036db8ae9069b7009377e6eebb79

It would make it easier for people to make use of this feature if the default prompt for pwsh was updated to use OSC 9;9, then people won't require any manual changes, and things would "just work"


How to test the feature -
=========================
Open Windows Terminal with pwsh profile in a directory and use the above linked prompt
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/83939604/119833916-21fb3480-bf1d-11eb-993a-05f4801921ab.png)
Press Ctrl-Shift-D
The new tab that opens will be in the same working directory.
(If the prompt is not updated to use OSC 9;9, then it opens in the default directory of C:\Users\<user>

comments.author: rkeithhill
comments.body: Neat feature but keep in mind that such a change in PowerShell would not be seen by folks who use a module like `oh-my-posh` or `posh-git` that provide their own custom prompt functions.

comments.author: TBBle
comments.body:
What if PowerShell emitted an OSC 9;9 sequence to the host whenever the CWD was changed on Windows? On POSIX-pathed platforms, it could emit OSC 7 instead. Then the functionality would be independent of whatever changes were made to the prompt.

I'm not sure off-hand if there are any places that would need to have this disabled, but the same question could be asked of adding it to the default `prompt()` as well.

comments.author: darkvertex
comments.body:
> Neat feature but keep in mind that such a change in PowerShell would not be seen by folks who use a module like `oh-my-posh` or `posh-git` that provide their own custom prompt functions.

FYI _oh-my-posh_ **v3.89.1** released in February 2021 introduced OSC 9;9 support with the `"osc99": true` json config key (and works just fine in WSL, too!)
